instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
customer brought in a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight. looked like liquid damage.  the screen lvds cable had messed up pins on 40 and 39.  checked the <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR>. its good. i jumped the <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR> to pin 1 of the <RESISTOR>R9704</RESISTOR> to test if the <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> was bad but no backlight still.  what is the best/ most simplified way of testing the voltage dividers/ mosfet? to find whats wrong? 

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: first think i would do is to check to see if the proper voltage is getting to the mosfet. then i would change the lvds connector and cable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Replace connector and cable and then measure voltages. Fuse is probably fucked too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
okay got the backlight working now.  but during the testing the computer wont boot fully into osx.  sometimes it makes it past the apple logo loading screen and into the login menu but when trying to log in it restarts. and most of the time its restarting during the end of the apple boot up process. any ideas? 

Thanks 
Nate

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
i guess i should have noted that i have replaced the <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR> (with a new full size) already and it was still not loading right.  it reboots when loading. and if i press the power button it just turns off immediately.  
Normally i find i have to hold the power button down for a good few seconds. 

i also tested the osx and its 100% working.

  (I really cannot believe how many i get in that are the <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR> issue though.)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Check corrosion around SMC reset circuit <CHIP>U5703</CHIP> <CHIP>U5001</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: hmm, i cleaned up around <CHIP>U5703</CHIP> & 5001.  it seems to not be restarting now but runs very slow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: also im not sure its the computer, but the keyboard seems to work in the option menu but when the computer loads osx the keyboard wont work.  it does not have the trackpad installed if that will affect the keyboard?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: You need trackpad attached on this for things to work in the OS. Attach trackpad!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
okay thats what i thought from previous experience.  

Thanks for all the help!
